title: Between 1 April 2018 and 31 March 2019, will an armed group from Yemen engage in a campaign that systematically kills 1,000 or more civilians in Yemen?
preds: UAE assault on port city fortifications will certainly have a high toll, but what class of casualty I think is anyone's guess.
The Yemenis needn't kill each other.  They have plenty of outside help in this endeavour.

“The coalition ground forces are now at the doorstep of this heavily fortified, heavily mined port city,” Egeland said. “Thousands of civilians are fleeing from the outskirts of Hodeidah, which is now a battle zone.” “We are now in a race against the clock, to really get enough supplies in through Hodeidah, which is very difficult given the continued severe restrictions on fuel and other imports by the coalition,” Egeland said. “War would mean nothing coming through.” Read more: http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2018/06/concern-mounts-coalition-advance-yemen-port-hodeidah.html#ixzz5HdzCgg6a
The group would have to be of Yemen origin. Besides that the 1000 deaths mark is pretty high.

“ on 11 May, the United Nations Human Rights office reported that April had been the deadliest month to date in 2018 in Yemen, with 236 civilian deaths and 238 civilian injuries in April alone; this was an increase from the 180 civilian casualties in March of that year.” Conflict intensity, (momentum or acceleration rate) doubled in last month. http://www.shiitenews.org/index.php/yemen/item/34391-april-deadliest-month-for-civilians-in-yemen-warns-un
Very possible! But concerned about the 1000 civilian death mark.

It is highly unlikely that an armed group from Yemen will systematically kill 1,000 civilians or more from 01/04/2018 - 31/03/2019. The group that produces the single greatest number of civilian casualties is the Saudi led coalition, however the question reads like the armed group must be from originate from Yemen, not an outside country.

KEY ASSUMPTIONS
1) Although indiscriminate targeting of civilians is a major cause of civilian deaths, systematic killing of civilians is not a major feature of this conflict 2) Systemic killing in the from of terrorist acts by AQAP or IS is a possibility, but both groups are weakened and constrained by ongoing Coalition military action  3) Another possibility is Saudi-led Coalition policies to blockade key Yemeni ports of entry which restrict humanitarian supplies leading to famine and disease outbreaks
BUT: Yemen has developed a resilient, widespread network of smuggling routes and informal economic structures that transcends front lines
AND: There is significant international pressure, especially from the US, to keep humanitarian aid flowing 4) There is a high degree of unpredictability on the ground:
-The war features a diverse network of numerous tribes, militias, and traditional armies connected by weak "marriage of convenience" alliances that are subject to realignment
-Major foreign backers of the warring parties, at the end of the day, have divergent interests (UAE and Saudi Arabia)
-The calcification of the front lines and the development of fully-functional regional mini-states along with control over local resources has given local political elites a strong incentive to continue to fight
-Ongoing peace efforts are not inclusive of major local parties and their grievances  POTENTIAL FLASH POINTS
----------------------
1) A schism between UAE and Saudi interests
2) Substantial Iranian support for the Houthi militia
3) Peace efforts that do not include key regional actors
4) A stepped up siege of key military objectives in Taiz or the port of Houdaibah

During the current Yemen Civil War, armed groups such as the Saudi-led coalition have engaged in aerial-bombardment that have targeted civilian areas. One recorded case by Human Rights Watch reported on 8 October 2016, a Saudi-led airstrike on a funeral ceremony that killed roughly 100 people and injured 500, including children. However, these engagements have been in separate/multiple campaigns, rather than a single 1,000 civilian fatalities event in one or more campaigns. Thus, the probability of an event where an armed group systematically kills 1000 or more civilians is between 10-19.
If by systematically we mean war, this is already taking place.
This has likely already occurred, but has not been publicized in western media
This situation is becoming more desparate, which could trigger actions of this size.
To busy fighting external entities to turn on themselves.
